page.title: 03HALE HOUSE AND PARK
page.content: THE BUILDING OF HALE HOUSE, WHICH IS MID-WAY BETWEEN HALE AND WOODGREEN, WAS STARTED IN 1715, AND A CLOCK PLACED IN THE ROOF IN 1718 IS STILL IN WORKING ORDER. THERE ARE SIXTEEN SERVANTS' ROOMS IN THE ATTIC BUT THE PRESENT OWNERS, WHO ARE IN RESIDENCE FOR ABOUT THREE DAYS A WEEK, EMPLOY ONLY A CLEANER IN THE HOUSE AND A GARDENER OUTSIDE. THERE ARE SEVENTEEN ROOMS IN THE BASEMENT, INCLUDING A GAME LARDER WHERE THEY STILL HANG BIRDS AND VENISON. THE HOUSE AND PARK ARE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC TEN TIMES A YEAR. THE DRIVE, WHICH LEADS TO THE FRONT DOOR, IS THE LONGEST STRAIGHT LIME TREE AVENUE IN ENGLAND. IT IS ONE MILE LONG AND THE TREES ARE AT LEAST 200 YEARS OLD.
